questions.question: What signifies the period known as prehistory?

choices.answer: Writing did not exist in any form.
Language was fully evolved.
Writing was very elementary.
Records were hidden away.

questions.question: What signifies the period known as history?

choices.answer: It started two million years ago.
It is a much longer period than prehistory.
It started two centuries ago.
There are written records.

questions.question: Why did towns need to be located near water to succeed?

choices.answer: Water attracted more people.
Water provided protection from warfare.
Water allowed for irrigation of crops.
Water allowed towns to be close to the marketplace.

questions.question: Which is true about the development of farming in Sumer?

choices.answer: Labor was plentiful, so farmers could hire plenty of help.
Women first learned to save seeds from grains
The land in Sumer was barren before the Sumerians.
Farmers relied mostly on rainfall to water large crops.

questions.question: Which example shows how prehistoric people adapted to their environments?

choices.answer: They fashioned clothes from plant leaves.
They made tools from stone.
They sewed furs with threads made from grasses.
They made tools from melted metal.

questions.question: How did early humans survive their harsh environments?

choices.answer: They lived in caves and rock shelters.
They built walls around their homes for protection.
They built homes out of wood.
They built homes out of stone.

questions.question: Why did early farmers use slash-and-burn agriculture?

choices.answer: to keep the soil fertile
they wanted the soil to get more sun.
to get rid of pests
to get rid of old crops

questions.question: Which is a change early farmers made to their environment?

choices.answer: burned undergrowth.
planted orchards.
created terraced farming.
built dams.

questions.question: Why did farming develop between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers?

choices.answer: It contained small stones mixed in the soil.
It is a marshy swamp.
It had palm trees that grew along the riverbanks.
It is a fertile floodplain.

questions.question: How did flooding rivers contribute to the rise of farming communities?

choices.answer: irrigated the crops when they overflowed.
created a marshy environment good for planting.
left rich soil when floodwaters receded.
provided water and stayed within their banks.

questions.question: Which group of people were probably the first to deliberately plant seeds?

choices.answer: children
women
gatherers
men

questions.question: Which is not required for the development of civilization?

choices.answer: cities
wheeled transportation
more food than is needed for survival
various kinds of work

questions.question: Which of these is not a necessary feature of civilization?

choices.answer: division of labor
cities
animals
food supplies beyond what farm families need

questions.question: Which description of nomads is the most accurate?

choices.answer: They move from one place to another in search of jobs.
They have no permanent home.
They migrate from one world region to another.
They travel in search of good hunting and bring their kill back

questions.question: Which statement best describes domestication?

choices.answer: living in farming villages
developing clearly defined family roles
raising crops for use in the home
taming animals for human use

questions.question: What happened when humans developed domestication?

choices.answer: Farming became women's work.
People began to build houses and form families.
Some people became herders.
Farming became less important in most places.

questions.question: Which statements about the agricultural revolution are true?

choices.answer: It occurred at different times in different places over many years.
It was the first time humans had adapted to the natural world.
It occurred suddenly in Mesopotamia.
It began when people first deliberately planted seeds.

questions.question: Which statements about the agricultural revolution are true?

choices.answer: Farming quickly eliminated herding as a way of life around the world.
It gave people a steady food supply for the first time.
Dramatic changes occurred in the way people lived.
It occurred only in regions where rivers flooded regularly.

questions.question: Which statements are not accurate descriptions of hunter-gatherers?

choices.answer: They keep herds of animals.
They search for wild plant foods.
Killing animals is a major task in their lives.
They live in permanent villages.

questions.question: Which statements are not accurate descriptions of hunter-gatherers?

choices.answer: Their food supply is less reliable than that of farmers.
They must move from place to place to follow animals.
Their food supply is more reliable than that of farmers.
They meet all of their food needs by killing animals.

questions.question: Which descriptions are true about a civilization?

choices.answer: Domesticated sheep, cattle, or goats provide most necessities.
Well-developed cities grew.
People do different jobs
Trade diminishes as more people make a wider variety of goods.

questions.question: Which descriptions are true about a civilization?

choices.answer: People work on large, organized projects.
Caring for herds of tame animals employs the majority of people.
Large numbers of people live close together.
Family life is centered on the production of crops.

questions.question: Which descriptions are true about a civilization?

choices.answer: Farming becomes unimportant in the economy.
Residents have no need for the herding of domesticated sheep
A few people are able to produce enough food for everyone.
People organize large projects such as levee-building.
